Award.AwardTitle: NSF Postdoctoral Fellowship in Biology FY 2015
Award.AbstractNarration:
This action funds an NSF Postdoctoral Research Fellowship in Biology for FY 2015, Broadening Participation. The fellowship supports a research and training plan in a host laboratory for the Fellow and a plan to broaden participation of groups under-represented in science. The title of the research plan for this fellowship to Alejandra I. Huerta is "Characterization and identification of a novel bacterial resistance mechanism that confers complete immunity to a major pathogen of rice." The host institution for this fellowship is Colorado State University, and the sponsoring scientists are Drs. Jan E. Leach and Lindsay Triplett.

The identification and characterization of new sources of resistance in rice is of particular importance in the context of global food security. Intensified rice production has resulted in higher disease pressures and yield loss due to bacterial disease such as bacterial leaf streak (BLS), caused by the bacterium Xanthomonas oryzae pv. oryzicola, yet no BLS resistance genes have been identified, hampering both an understanding of disease causation and prevention. The fellowship research investigates how the pathogen both triggers and suppresses resistance in an ancient cultivated variety of rice, Carolina Gold, grown in the United States by elucidating mechanisms at the molecular level, i.e., the role of surface-exposed amino acid residues in proteins produced by the pathogen and that interact with the host.

Training goals include gaining mastery of molecular tools in plant biology, bioinformatics including genome mining, and science communication. Educational outreach is through a partnership with the U.S. Department of Education Migrant Education Program to develop hands-on, tangible and accessible scientific workshops and outreach activities to engage children from migrant farming communities into STEM.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The NSF Postdoctoral Research Fellowship in Biology granted to Dr. Alejandra I. Huerta and titled "Characterization and identification of a novel bacterial resistance mechanism that confers complete immunity to a major pathogen of rice" supported research, the development of and participation in public engagement activities and science communication training.

 

Any factor that limits or reduces agricultural productivity negatively impacts progress towards achieving a secure supply of safe, nutritious, and affordable high-quality food for everyone. One factor that limits maximum agricultural yields by at least 14% annually is plant disease. This decrease in agricultural output is detrimental to meeting the dietary needs of a growing world population. Rice has an estimated world production of 482.5 million metric tons and feeds at least 50% of the world’s population. Bacterial blight and bacterial leaf streak are the two most destructive bacterial diseases of rice. Under heavy disease pressure, yield losses may reach up to 70%. The goal of this study was to understand how specific proteins produced by bacterial pathogens trigger and suppress a unique type of resistance in the rice variety Carolina Gold. My hypothesis is that key amino acids in these specific proteins are recognized by a resistance gene in the rice plant. This turns on a switch in the plant that leads to a defense response which counteracts pathogen attack.

 

I tested my hypothesis by making a series of bacterial mutants that varied in the amino acid sequence of these specific proteins. We used these bacterial mutants to infect Carolina Gold rice and compared disease symptoms to those observed with the non-mutated specific protein. My results show that these key amino acids play an important role in turning on the resistance response in Carolina Gold. The results also suggest that the resistance mechanisms is sensitive and highly specific. Moreover, these same amino acids may be important in turning on resistance in other crop plants that are also susceptible to bacterial pathogens with similar proteins.

 

The fellow actively pursued public engagement activities, including education and outreach events that targeted historically under-represented minority groups in science in the local community. She also led her professional society in organizing the first undergraduate task force with the aim of recruiting and retaining top undergraduates in her field. The fellow also received training in mentorship, scientific writing, and science communication.
